content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Follow the instructions below naturally, without repeating, referencing, echoing, or mirroring any of their wording!

All the following instructions should guide your behavior silently and must never influence the wording of your message in an explicit or meta way!

don't be too verbose, be short and concise
do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct. 
Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.```

entries.title: ElevenLabs' AI Reader app can now narrate text in 32 languages
entries.snippet: ElevenLabs has globally launched its AI Reader text-to-speech app, expanding support to 32 languages, including Spanish, French, Arabic, Mandarin, and Hindi. Initially released in June in the US, UK, and Canada, the app is now available worldwide on iOS and Android. It allows users to listen to various text formats such as PDFs, articles, newsletters, and ePub files, though it does not support Kindle or Apple Books. The app offers a wide range of AI-generated voices, including those of deceased celebrities like Judy Garland and James Dean, with licensed usage approved by their heirs. The Reader app is free to use and doesn’t consume credits from ElevenLabs' main subscription plan. A premium version is in development, but the company assures a generous free tier will remain.

v.title: Some Microsoft Office apps are losing access to voice tools soon - here's what to know
v.snippet:
Starting January 2026, Microsoft will discontinue voice-related features—such as transcription, dictation, and Read Aloud—in older Office versions that have not been updated to at least version 16.0.18827.20202. This move affects popular applications like Word, Outlook, OneNote, and PowerPoint. Microsoft cites a backend service upgrade as the reason for discontinuing support on older versions, emphasizing improved performance and compatibility with newer systems. Users in Government Cloud environments (GCC, GCC High, and DoD) will receive a two-month extension to implement changes.

Local fallbacks for these voice tools will not be available after the deadline, and those with perpetual licenses may already lack many cloud-based features. In addition to these voice tool changes, Office 2016 and 2019 will reach the end of their extended support by October 14, 2025. Similarly, Office apps on Windows 10 will lose support later in 2025, coinciding with Windows 10's own end-of-life status. These shifts are encouraging broader adoption of Microsoft’s latest software, with Windows 11 surpassing Windows 10 in installations as of July 2025.

entries.title: Voicebox: Text-Guided Multilingual Universal Speech Generation at Scale
Google Docs Just Added This Futuristic Feature
entries.snippet: On February 24, 2016, Google announced the addition of advanced voice command capabilities to Google Docs, significantly enhancing its voice dictation functionality. This new feature allows users to execute various formatting and editing tasks—such as bolding text, cutting words, and manipulating tables—simply by speaking commands aloud. While voice dictation has been available in Docs for several months, this marks the first time that complex editing commands can be performed via voice. To access this functionality, users must navigate to the “Tools” menu and select “Voice Typing,” which activates a microphone icon ready to accept voice input. It's important to note that this feature is currently only compatible with the Chrome browser and accepts voice commands exclusively in English.

entries.title: Millions of Kindle users given big device update & it impacts the way you enjoy free books
entries.snippet:
Amazon has released a major update for 11th- and 12th-generation Kindle devices, introducing a new "Assistive Reader" feature designed primarily to help users with impaired vision. This functionality uses Text-to-Speech (TTS) technology to read books aloud, providing an alternative to traditional audiobooks. It integrates with the Kindle app across various platforms and supports real-time text highlighting during playback. Users must pair Bluetooth headphones with their Kindle devices, as they lack built-in headphone jacks.

Assistive Reader supports multiple languages, including English, Spanish, German, and French. However, not all ebooks are compatible; only those with the Enhanced Typesetting feature can use this tool. The feature was initially tested in July but temporarily withdrawn. Alongside the update, Amazon is promoting its Kindle Unlimited subscription service, which offers access to millions of books and is currently available with a 30-day free trial. The update is expected to enhance Kindle's appeal, especially among readers looking for more accessible reading options.

entries.title: Say Anything
entries.snippet: This article from Wired, titled "Say Anything" and dated May 1, 2000, examines the progress and state of machine-based language communication technologies. It categorizes key developments into four research-driven areas: speech processing, speech synthesis, machine translation (MT), and natural language processing (NLP). Speech processing handles speech-to-text via applications like continuous speech recognition and command-and-control systems. Speech synthesis converts text to intelligible speech, enhancing user interaction. Machine translation translates text across languages, where unassisted MT is suited for quick "gisting" and assisted MT is used when accuracy is critical. NLP interprets meanings in written language and supports databases and email response systems. A key innovation in NLP is the development of commonsense knowledge bases, like Cycorp’s Cyc, which help machines better understand real-world context. Although a real-time universal translator remains elusive for complex conversations, focused-use applications now offer functional and practical solutions for limited interactions such as booking services or navigating simple commands.

entries.title: IIIT-H gives voice to tribal languages with AI-powered tools
entries.snippet:
The International Institute of Information Technology, Hyderabad (IIITH), has developed AI-powered text-to-speech (TTS) tools to support Adi Vaani, a recently launched translator for tribal languages by the Indian government. These tools currently support Santali, Mundari, and Bhili, with Gondi in development, and are built using speech samples recorded by native speakers. IIITH is also working on TTS tools for Telangana's tribal languages, including Koya, Kolami, Naikdi, Chenchu, Kaikadi (Yerukala), Lambadi, Nakkala, and Konda Kammara.

Alongside TTS, IIITH created translation systems for English, Hindi, and Santali using data from the Tribal Research Institute in Odisha. The tools are cloud-deployed for broad device compatibility. Radhika Mamidi, leading the initiative, emphasized its goal of improving accessibility to education, healthcare, and government resources in low-resource tribal languages. While still in the Beta phase, the systems are expected to improve with user feedback. IIITH also promotes online content development in Telangana-origin languages through its Indic-Wiki program. The project, in collaboration with institutions like IIT Delhi, is seen as key to preserving endangered tribal languages and bridging the digital divide.
